title: Forces - friction between blocks and surface

content.question: Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight. A sled of mass <math alttext="m" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>m</mi></math> slides down a rough ramp with a constant speed <math alttext="v sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>v</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></mstyle></math>. The angle between the ramp and the horizontal is <math alttext="theta" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi>θ</mi></mstyle></math>, as shown in Figure <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>. The ramp smoothly transitions to a horizontal surface. The coefficients of static and kinetic friction between the sled and the ramp are <math alttext="mu sub s" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>μ</mi><mi>s</mi></msub></math> and <math alttext="mu sub k" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>μ</mi><mi>k</mi></msub></math>, respectively. The ramp and the horizontal surface are made of identical materials. (a) The dot in Figure <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> represents the sled when the sled is sliding down the ramp at a constant speed. Draw and label arrows that represent the forces (not components) that are exerted on the sled. Each force in your free-body diagram must be represented by a distinct arrow starting on, and pointing away from the dot.

(b)i. Starting with Newton’s second law, derive an expression for the force of friction exerted on the sled. Express your answer in terms of <math alttext="m" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>m</mi></math>, <math alttext="mu sub s" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>μ</mi><mi>s</mi></msub></math>, <math alttext="mu sub k" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>μ</mi><mi>k</mi></msub></math>, <math alttext="theta" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>θ</mi></math>, and physical constants, as appropriate.

ii. Derive an expression for the coefficient of kinetic friction between the object and the ramp. Express your answer in terms of <math alttext="m" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>m</mi></math>, <math alttext="mu sub s" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>μ</mi><mi>s</mi></msub></math>, <math alttext="mu sub k" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>μ</mi><mi>k</mi></msub></math>, <math alttext="theta" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>θ</mi></math>, and physical constants, as appropriate.

At <math alttext="t equals t sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>t</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mstyle></math> the sled reaches the bottom of the ramp and from <math alttext="t equals t sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>t</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mstyle></math> to <math alttext="t equals 2 t sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><msub><mi>t</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mstyle></math> the sled continues to slide on the horizontal surface, as shown in Figure <math alttext="3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn></math>. The sled comes to rest sometime after <math alttext="t equals 2 t sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><msub><mi>t</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mstyle></math>.(c) On the axes shown in Figure <math alttext="4" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>4</mn></math>, sketch a graph of the speed <math alttext="v" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>v</mi></math> of the sled as a function of time from <math alttext="t equals 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mstyle></math> to <math alttext="t equals 2 t sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><msub><mi>t</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mstyle></math>.

(d) Indicate how the shape of the graph between <math alttext="t equals 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="t equals t sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>t</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mstyle></math>, sketched in part (c) would change, if at all, if the angle of the ramp were increased. Justify your claim.
